metadata.description: Scenario-Based Study Companion for GCP fundamentals - introductory overview of Google Cloud services, infrastructure, and core concepts.

question.title: GCP Resource Hierarchy
question.scenario: A multinational corporation is setting up their Google Cloud environment. They need to organize resources for multiple departments across different regions while maintaining centralized billing and policy management.
question.question-text: Which resource hierarchy level serves as the root node for organizing all GCP resources and enables centralized billing?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: The Organization is the top-level container in GCP's resource hierarchy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The Organization resource is the root node of the GCP resource hierarchy, tied to a Google Workspace or Cloud Identity account. It enables centralized visibility and control over all cloud resources, including billing, IAM policies, and organization-wide settings.

ul.li: The hierarchy is: Organization > Folders > Projects > Resources.
Folders allow grouping projects by department, team, or environment.
IAM policies are inherited downward through the hierarchy.
Projects are the basic unit for resource management and billing.

question.title: Compute Engine Basics
question.scenario: A startup needs to deploy a web application that requires full control over the operating system, custom kernel modules, and specific hardware configurations.
question.question-text: Which GCP compute service provides virtual machines with full OS-level control?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Compute Engine is GCP's Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offering.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Compute Engine provides virtual machines (VMs) that run on Google's infrastructure. You have full control over the OS, can install any software, configure networking, and choose machine types. It's ideal when you need infrastructure-level control.

ul.li: Compute Engine supports custom machine types for precise resource allocation.
Preemptible and Spot VMs offer significant cost savings for fault-tolerant workloads.
App Engine is PaaS; Cloud Functions is serverless functions; Cloud Run is serverless containers.
Live migration keeps VMs running during maintenance events.

question.title: App Engine Overview
question.scenario: A development team wants to deploy a Python web application without managing servers, patching, or infrastructure. They want automatic scaling based on traffic.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a fully managed platform for building and deploying applications without infrastructure management?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: App Engine is GCP's Platform as a Service (PaaS) for application hosting.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: App Engine is a fully managed PaaS that handles infrastructure, scaling, and operations. Developers deploy code, and Google manages servers, load balancing, and scaling. It supports multiple languages including Python, Java, Node.js, Go, and PHP.

ul.li: App Engine Standard provides fast scaling and language-specific runtimes.
App Engine Flexible runs custom containers with more control.
Automatic scaling responds to traffic patterns without configuration.
Built-in versioning enables traffic splitting for A/B testing and canary deployments.

question.title: Cloud Storage Classes
question.scenario: A media company needs to store video archives that are rarely accessed but must be retained for 10 years for compliance. They want the lowest storage cost possible.
question.question-text: Which Cloud Storage class provides the lowest cost for data accessed less than once a year?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Archive storage is designed for data accessed less than once per year.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Archive storage class offers the lowest storage cost for data that you plan to access less than once a year. It's ideal for long-term backups, disaster recovery, and regulatory archives. Retrieval costs are higher but storage costs are minimal.

ul.li: Standard: Frequently accessed data, highest storage cost.
Nearline: Accessed less than once per month, 30-day minimum storage.
Coldline: Accessed less than once per quarter, 90-day minimum storage.
Archive: Accessed less than once per year, 365-day minimum storage.
All classes have the same APIs, latency, and durability (11 nines).

question.title: BigQuery Introduction
question.scenario: A retail company wants to analyze petabytes of sales data to identify trends. They need a serverless solution that can run complex SQL queries without managing infrastructure.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a serverless, highly scalable data warehouse for analytics?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: BigQuery is Google's serverless enterprise data warehouse.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: BigQuery is a fully managed, serverless data warehouse that enables scalable analysis over petabytes of data. It uses standard SQL, separates compute from storage, and provides real-time analytics without infrastructure management.

ul.li: BigQuery uses columnar storage format for efficient analytical queries.
Pricing models include on-demand (per TB scanned) and flat-rate (reserved slots).
BigQuery ML enables machine learning models using SQL.
Streaming inserts allow real-time data ingestion.
Federated queries can access external data sources.

question.title: VPC Fundamentals
question.scenario: An enterprise is migrating to GCP and needs to create isolated network environments for development, staging, and production with controlled communication between them.
question.question-text: What is the core networking construct in GCP that provides private, isolated network space for resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC provides software-defined networking for GCP resources.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is a global, private network that spans all GCP regions. It provides IP address management, firewall rules, routes, and network connectivity for Compute Engine VMs, GKE clusters, and other resources.

ul.li: VPCs are global resources; subnets are regional.
VPC Peering connects VPCs for private communication.
Shared VPC allows multiple projects to use a common VPC.
Firewall rules are stateful and can filter by IP, protocol, and port.
Private Google Access allows VMs without external IPs to reach Google APIs.

question.title: IAM Fundamentals
question.scenario: A company needs to grant a contractor read-only access to Cloud Storage buckets in a specific project without giving access to other services or projects.
question.question-text: Which GCP service manages access control by defining who (identity) can do what (role) on which resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IAM (Identity and Access Management) controls who can do what on GCP resources.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud IAM provides fine-grained access control for GCP resources. It uses the principle of least privilege by binding identities (users, groups, service accounts) to roles (collections of permissions) on specific resources.

ul.li: Roles can be primitive (Owner, Editor, Viewer), predefined, or custom.
Service accounts are identities for applications and VMs.
IAM policies are inherited through the resource hierarchy.
IAM Conditions enable attribute-based access control.
Recommender suggests least-privilege role improvements.

question.title: Kubernetes Engine Overview
question.scenario: A company wants to run containerized microservices with automatic scaling, load balancing, and self-healing capabilities without managing the Kubernetes control plane.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a managed Kubernetes environment for deploying containerized applications?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GKE is Google's managed Kubernetes service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) is a managed Kubernetes service that simplifies container orchestration. Google manages the control plane, automatic upgrades, and cluster health while you focus on deploying applications.

ul.li: GKE Autopilot mode manages the entire cluster, including nodes.
GKE Standard mode gives more control over node configuration.
Workload Identity links Kubernetes service accounts to GCP IAM.
GKE integrates with Cloud Build, Artifact Registry, and Cloud Deploy.
Multi-cluster services enable global load balancing across clusters.

question.title: Regions and Zones
question.scenario: A gaming company needs to deploy servers close to users in Asia for low latency while ensuring redundancy in case of datacenter failures.
question.question-text: What is the relationship between GCP regions and zones?

choices.choice: A region contains multiple zones, which are isolated data centers
A zone contains multiple regions for global distribution
Regions and zones are interchangeable terms
Zones span multiple regions for redundancy

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Regions are geographic areas containing multiple independent zones.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A region is a specific geographic location (e.g., us-central1, asia-east1) that contains multiple zones. Each zone is an isolated data center within a region with independent power, cooling, and networking. Deploying across zones provides high availability within a region.

ul.li: Zones are named as region-zone (e.g., us-central1-a, us-central1-b).
Most regions have 3 or more zones.
Regional resources span multiple zones automatically.
Zonal resources exist in a single zone and require manual redundancy.
Multi-region locations (like US or EU) span multiple regions for global services.

question.title: Cloud SQL Overview
question.scenario: A company is migrating a WordPress application to GCP and needs a managed MySQL database that handles backups, replication, and patching automatically.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides fully managed relational databases for MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud SQL is GCP's managed relational database service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud SQL is a fully managed relational database service supporting MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server. It handles provisioning, replication, backups, failover, and patches. It's ideal for traditional relational workloads migrating to the cloud.

ul.li: High availability configuration provides automatic failover to a standby.
Read replicas scale read-heavy workloads.
Private IP keeps database traffic within your VPC.
Cloud SQL Auth Proxy provides secure, encrypted connections.
Database Migration Service helps migrate to Cloud SQL.

question.title: Service Accounts
question.scenario: An application running on a Compute Engine VM needs to access Cloud Storage buckets and BigQuery datasets without storing credentials in the application code.
question.question-text: What identity type should be used to grant GCP resources access to other GCP services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Service accounts are identities for applications and services, not humans.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Service accounts are special Google accounts that represent applications rather than users. VMs and other resources can be assigned a service account, which provides credentials automatically through the metadata server without embedding secrets in code.

ul.li: Default service accounts are created automatically but should be replaced with custom ones.
Service account keys can be created but are a security risk if not managed properly.
Workload Identity Federation allows external identities to impersonate service accounts.
Service account impersonation enables short-lived credential use.
Scopes and IAM roles together determine what a service account can do.

question.title: Cloud Functions
question.scenario: A developer needs to process images uploaded to Cloud Storage by generating thumbnails. The function should run only when new files are uploaded and scale automatically.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides event-driven serverless functions that execute in response to cloud events?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Functions is GCP's Function as a Service (FaaS) offering.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Functions is a serverless execution environment for building event-driven applications. Functions can be triggered by Cloud Storage events, Pub/Sub messages, HTTP requests, or Firestore changes. Google manages all infrastructure, scaling, and availability.

ul.li: 1st gen functions support Node.js, Python, Go, Java, .NET, Ruby, and PHP.
2nd gen functions are built on Cloud Run and offer longer timeouts and larger instances.
Eventarc provides a unified eventing experience for 2nd gen functions.
Cold starts can affect latency for infrequently called functions.
Minimum instances setting keeps functions warm to reduce cold starts.

question.title: Cloud Load Balancing
question.scenario: A global e-commerce site needs to distribute traffic across multiple regions to provide low-latency access for users worldwide while handling SSL termination.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides global, software-defined load balancing with a single anycast IP?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Load Balancing distributes traffic globally using Google's network.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Load Balancing is a fully distributed, software-defined service that provides global load balancing. It uses a single anycast IP address, routes users to the closest healthy backend, and handles millions of requests per second with automatic scaling.

ul.li: HTTP(S) Load Balancing is layer 7 and supports URL maps and SSL termination.
TCP/UDP Load Balancing operates at layer 4 for non-HTTP traffic.
Internal Load Balancing is for traffic within your VPC.
SSL Certificates can be Google-managed for automatic renewal.
Cloud Armor integration provides DDoS protection and WAF capabilities.

question.title: Cloud Spanner
question.scenario: A financial services company needs a relational database that provides strong consistency, horizontal scaling, and high availability across multiple regions for their global transaction processing system.
question.question-text: Which GCP database service combines the benefits of relational databases with horizontal scalability?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Spanner is a globally distributed, strongly consistent relational database.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Spanner is a fully managed relational database that combines the structure of relational databases with the scalability of NoSQL. It provides ACID transactions, SQL queries, and automatic sharding across regions while maintaining strong consistency.

ul.li: TrueTime API enables global consistency using atomic clocks and GPS.
Spanner can scale from 1 node to thousands of nodes.
Multi-region configurations provide 99.999% availability SLA.
Spanner supports both Google Standard SQL and PostgreSQL dialects.
Change streams enable real-time data replication to BigQuery or other systems.

question.title: Cloud Run
question.scenario: A team wants to deploy a containerized API that scales to zero when not in use, automatically scales up with traffic, and doesn't require managing Kubernetes clusters.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides serverless container execution without infrastructure management?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Run is serverless for containers - bring any container, it handles the rest.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Run is a fully managed compute platform that runs stateless containers. It automatically scales based on incoming requests (including to zero), handles HTTPS, and charges only for resources used during request processing. Any language or library that can run in a container works on Cloud Run.

ul.li: Cloud Run services handle HTTP requests; Cloud Run jobs handle batch workloads.
Container images are stored in Artifact Registry or Container Registry.
Cloud Run can connect to VPC networks via Serverless VPC Access.
Second generation execution environment provides full Linux compatibility.
Always-on CPU allocation is available for background processing.

question.title: Firestore Overview
question.scenario: A mobile game developer needs a real-time NoSQL database that syncs data across devices and works offline, with automatic scaling.
question.question-text: Which GCP database provides real-time synchronization, offline support, and automatic scaling for mobile and web applications?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Firestore is a serverless NoSQL document database with real-time sync.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Firestore is a flexible, scalable NoSQL cloud database for mobile, web, and server development. It offers real-time listeners for instant data synchronization, offline support for mobile apps, and ACID transactions. It automatically scales to handle millions of operations per second.

ul.li: Firestore uses a document-collection data model with hierarchical structure.
Native mode provides all features; Datastore mode maintains API compatibility.
Security Rules control access without server-side code for mobile/web apps.
Multi-region deployments provide automatic replication and failover.
Composite indexes support complex queries on multiple fields.

question.title: Cloud KMS
question.scenario: A healthcare company needs to encrypt sensitive patient data with keys they control, with the ability to rotate keys automatically and audit key usage.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides centralized management of encryption keys for cloud services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud KMS manages cryptographic keys for your cloud services.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Key Management Service (KMS) lets you create, use, rotate, and destroy cryptographic keys. It integrates with other GCP services for encryption at rest, provides audit logging, and supports hardware security modules (HSMs) for additional protection.

ul.li: Key types include symmetric (AES-256) and asymmetric (RSA, EC).
Cloud HSM provides FIPS 140-2 Level 3 certified key storage.
Customer-Managed Encryption Keys (CMEK) give you control over GCP service encryption.
External Key Manager (EKM) allows using keys from external key management systems.
Automatic key rotation creates new key versions without re-encryption.

question.title: Cloud CDN
question.scenario: A media streaming company wants to cache and deliver video content to users globally with low latency, reducing load on their origin servers.
question.question-text: Which GCP service caches content at Google's edge locations for faster delivery to users?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud CDN is Google's content delivery network for caching at edge locations.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud CDN (Content Delivery Network) caches content at Google's globally distributed edge points of presence. It reduces latency by serving content from locations closer to users, decreases origin server load, and integrates seamlessly with Cloud Load Balancing.

ul.li: Cache modes control what gets cached: CACHE_ALL_STATIC, USE_ORIGIN_HEADERS, or FORCE_CACHE_ALL.
Signed URLs and signed cookies protect premium content.
Cache invalidation removes content before TTL expiration.
Media CDN is optimized for video streaming with large file optimization.
Cloud CDN logging provides detailed cache hit/miss metrics.

question.title: Cloud Shell
question.scenario: A developer needs immediate command-line access to GCP resources without installing any software on their local machine.
question.question-text: Which GCP feature provides a browser-based shell environment with pre-installed tools and 5GB of persistent storage?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Shell is a browser-based command line with pre-installed tools.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Shell provides a free, browser-based terminal with a temporary Compute Engine VM. It includes pre-installed tools like gcloud, kubectl, and terraform, plus 5GB of persistent home directory storage. It's automatically authenticated with your GCP credentials.

ul.li: Cloud Shell Editor provides a web-based VS Code-like IDE.
Sessions automatically terminate after 1 hour of inactivity.
Home directory persists across sessions; VM is ephemeral.
Web preview allows testing web applications on ports 8080-8084.
Boost mode provides a larger VM for resource-intensive tasks.

question.title: Pub/Sub Messaging
question.scenario: A company needs to decouple their microservices architecture, allowing services to communicate asynchronously with guaranteed message delivery even during service outages.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides fully managed, real-time messaging with at-least-once delivery?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Pub/Sub is GCP's managed messaging service for decoupling systems.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Pub/Sub is a fully managed messaging service that enables asynchronous communication between services. Publishers send messages to topics; subscribers receive messages from subscriptions. It guarantees at-least-once delivery and scales automatically.

ul.li: Push subscriptions deliver messages to HTTP endpoints; pull subscriptions require polling.
Message ordering can be enabled with ordering keys.
Dead-letter topics capture messages that fail processing.
Exactly-once delivery is available with Dataflow integration.
Pub/Sub Lite offers lower cost for high-throughput scenarios with zonal availability.

question.title: Bigtable
question.scenario: An IoT company needs to store and analyze billions of sensor readings with single-digit millisecond latency for real-time dashboards and time-series analysis.
question.question-text: Which GCP database is designed for low-latency, high-throughput workloads with massive datasets?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Bigtable is a wide-column NoSQL database for low-latency, high-throughput workloads.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Bigtable is a fully managed, scalable NoSQL database service for large analytical and operational workloads. It's the same database that powers Google Search, Maps, and Gmail. It provides consistent sub-10ms latency and scales to petabytes of data.

ul.li: Bigtable uses a wide-column data model similar to HBase.
Data is stored sorted by row key; schema design is critical for performance.
Clusters can be resized without downtime; replication provides high availability.
Native integration with Hadoop, Dataflow, and Dataproc for big data processing.
Time-series data benefits from row key designs that include timestamps.

question.title: VPC Firewall Rules
question.scenario: A security team needs to control which traffic can reach their web servers, allowing HTTP/HTTPS from the internet but blocking all other incoming traffic.
question.question-text: What GCP feature controls inbound and outbound network traffic to VPC resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC firewall rules filter traffic based on IP, port, and protocol.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VPC firewall rules control ingress (incoming) and egress (outgoing) traffic to and from VM instances. Rules are stateful, meaning return traffic is automatically allowed. You can specify allowed/denied traffic based on IP ranges, protocols, ports, and service accounts or network tags.

ul.li: Firewall rules are defined at the VPC level but apply to individual instances.
Rules use priority (0-65535); lower numbers have higher priority.
Target tags or service accounts determine which VMs rules apply to.
Implied rules deny all ingress and allow all egress by default.
Firewall Insights provides analysis and recommendations for rule optimization.

question.title: Preemptible VMs
question.scenario: A research team needs to run batch processing jobs that can tolerate interruptions. They want to minimize costs for compute resources.
question.question-text: Which Compute Engine VM type offers up to 80% cost savings but may be terminated by GCP with 30-second notice?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Preemptible/Spot VMs are short-lived, discounted instances for fault-tolerant workloads.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Preemptible VMs (now called Spot VMs) are highly affordable, short-lived instances that can be preempted by GCP when resources are needed. They last a maximum of 24 hours and can be terminated with 30-second notice. They're ideal for batch jobs, rendering, and fault-tolerant workloads.

ul.li: Spot VMs are the newer version with no 24-hour maximum lifetime.
Managed Instance Groups can automatically recreate preempted instances.
Preemption rate varies by zone, time, and machine type.
Committed use discounts (1 or 3 years) offer savings for steady-state workloads.
Combine with Instance Groups for automatic replacement of terminated VMs.

question.title: Cloud Billing
question.scenario: A company with multiple development teams wants to track cloud spending by team and set alerts when spending approaches budget limits.
question.question-text: Which GCP feature allows you to set spending thresholds and receive alerts when costs approach or exceed defined amounts?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Budget alerts notify you when spending reaches defined thresholds.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Budgets and budget alerts in Cloud Billing let you set spending targets and receive notifications when costs approach or exceed those amounts. You can set multiple thresholds (e.g., 50%, 90%, 100%) and receive email alerts or trigger Pub/Sub notifications for automated responses.

ul.li: Budgets can be set per billing account, project, or by label.
Budget scope can include or exclude specific services.
Pub/Sub integration enables automated actions like shutting down resources.
Cost breakdown reports show spending by service, SKU, project, and labels.
Billing export to BigQuery enables detailed cost analysis and forecasting.

question.title: Cloud Interconnect
question.scenario: An enterprise needs a dedicated, high-bandwidth, low-latency connection between their on-premises data center and GCP for sensitive workloads that cannot traverse the public internet.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides dedicated physical connections between on-premises networks and Google's network?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Dedicated Interconnect provides physical connections to Google's network.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Dedicated Interconnect provides direct physical connections between your on-premises network and Google's network at colocation facilities. It offers 10 or 100 Gbps circuits, lower latency than internet, and traffic doesn't traverse the public internet, meeting compliance requirements.

ul.li: Partner Interconnect provides similar benefits through service provider partners.
Cloud VPN uses encrypted tunnels over the internet, suitable for lower bandwidth needs.
Cross-Cloud Interconnect connects GCP to other cloud providers.
SLA of 99.99% requires specific redundancy configurations.
Interconnect traffic can use Private Google Access for API access.

question.title: Cloud Storage Buckets
question.scenario: A company needs to store static website assets, user-uploaded files, and application backups in an object storage system with global accessibility.
question.question-text: What is the top-level container for storing objects in Cloud Storage?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Buckets are containers that hold objects (files) in Cloud Storage.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: A bucket is a container for storing objects in Cloud Storage. Each bucket has a globally unique name, a storage class, a location (region, dual-region, or multi-region), and access control settings. Objects stored in buckets are immutable - they can only be replaced, not modified in place.

ul.li: Bucket names must be globally unique across all of GCP.
Object versioning preserves previous versions when objects are overwritten.
Lifecycle rules automate deletion or storage class changes.
Uniform bucket-level access simplifies permission management.
Retention policies and bucket locks enforce compliance requirements.

question.title: Cloud Armor
question.scenario: An e-commerce website is experiencing DDoS attacks and needs to protect their HTTP(S) load balancer with web application firewall rules and rate limiting.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides DDoS protection and web application firewall (WAF) capabilities?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Armor provides DDoS protection and WAF for HTTP(S) load balancers.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Armor is a security service that protects applications behind HTTP(S) load balancers from DDoS attacks and application-layer attacks. It provides WAF rules, rate limiting, adaptive protection using machine learning, and integration with the OWASP ModSecurity Core Rule Set.

ul.li: Security policies contain rules that match traffic and take actions (allow, deny, throttle).
Preconfigured rules protect against OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities.
Bot management identifies and manages automated traffic.
Named IP lists allow rules based on Google's threat intelligence.
Adaptive Protection uses ML to detect and mitigate sophisticated attacks.

question.title: Labels and Resource Organization
question.scenario: A company needs to categorize cloud resources by cost center, environment (dev/staging/prod), and owner to track spending and manage resources effectively.
question.question-text: What GCP feature allows you to attach key-value pairs to resources for organization and cost allocation?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Labels are key-value pairs attached to GCP resources for organization.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Labels are key-value pairs that you can attach to GCP resources like VMs, disks, and buckets. They help organize resources, filter billing reports, and manage resources at scale. Labels are user-defined and don't affect resource behavior.

ul.li: Labels appear in billing exports for cost allocation analysis.
Maximum 64 labels per resource; keys and values have length limits.
Network tags (different from labels) control firewall rule application.
IAM Conditions can reference labels for fine-grained access control.
Resource Manager tags (newer feature) enable hierarchical organization and IAM.

question.title: Managed Instance Groups
question.scenario: A web application needs to automatically add VM instances during peak traffic and remove them during quiet periods, with automatic replacement of failed instances.
question.question-text: Which Compute Engine feature provides auto-scaling, auto-healing, and rolling updates for groups of identical VMs?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Managed Instance Groups (MIGs) automate scaling, healing, and updates for VMs.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Managed Instance Groups (MIGs) create and manage groups of identical VM instances from a template. They provide auto-scaling based on metrics, auto-healing with health checks, rolling updates for zero-downtime deployments, and integration with load balancers.

ul.li: Regional MIGs spread instances across zones for high availability.
Autoscaling can use CPU, load balancing, custom metrics, or schedules.
Canary updates allow testing new configurations on a subset of instances.
Instance templates define machine type, disk, network, and startup scripts.
Stateful MIGs preserve instance names, IPs, and persistent disks.

question.title: Cloud DNS
question.scenario: A company needs to manage DNS records for their domain, with low-latency responses worldwide and integration with their GCP infrastructure.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides scalable, reliable, and managed authoritative DNS hosting?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud DNS is GCP's managed DNS service with 100% availability SLA.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud DNS is a scalable, reliable, and managed authoritative DNS service running on Google's global network. It provides low-latency DNS responses, supports standard record types, and offers a 100% availability SLA. It integrates with other GCP services and supports DNSSEC.

ul.li: Public zones serve external DNS queries; private zones serve internal VPC queries.
DNS policies enable split-horizon DNS and response policies.
Cloud Domains is for domain registration; Cloud DNS is for DNS hosting.
Health-checking based routing enables active-active and failover configurations.
Logging provides visibility into DNS queries for security analysis.

question.title: VPC Service Controls
question.scenario: A financial institution needs to prevent data exfiltration from their BigQuery datasets by restricting API access to only authorized VPCs and IP ranges.
question.question-text: Which GCP feature creates security perimeters around GCP resources to prevent data exfiltration?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VPC Service Controls create perimeters that restrict data movement.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: VPC Service Controls create security perimeters around GCP resources like BigQuery, Cloud Storage, and GKE. They prevent data exfiltration by restricting which networks, identities, and services can access resources within the perimeter, even if IAM permissions would otherwise allow access.

ul.li: Service perimeters define which projects and services are protected.
Access levels specify conditions for accessing perimeter resources.
Ingress and egress rules control data flow across perimeter boundaries.
Dry-run mode allows testing perimeters without enforcement.
VPC Service Controls work alongside IAM, not as a replacement.

question.title: Machine Types
question.scenario: A development team needs to choose the right VM size for their application, balancing cost and performance for a memory-intensive workload.
question.question-text: Which machine type family is optimized for workloads requiring high memory-to-CPU ratios?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Memory-optimized machines provide the highest memory-to-CPU ratio.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Memory-optimized (M series) machine types are designed for workloads requiring high memory per CPU, such as in-memory databases, real-time analytics, and SAP HANA. They offer up to 12 TB of memory per VM with the highest memory-to-CPU ratios available.

ul.li: General-purpose (E2, N1, N2) balance price and performance for most workloads.
Compute-optimized (C2, C2D) provide highest per-core performance for HPC.
Accelerator-optimized (A2) include attached GPUs for ML training.
Custom machine types allow exact CPU/memory ratios within limits.
Extended memory allows adding more RAM to standard machine types.

question.title: Persistent Disks
question.scenario: A database server needs reliable block storage that persists independently of VM lifecycle, with automatic encryption and the ability to take snapshots.
question.question-text: What is the durable, high-performance block storage service for Compute Engine VMs?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Persistent Disks provide block storage that survives VM stops and deletions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Persistent Disks are durable block storage devices that persist independently of Compute Engine VMs. They're automatically encrypted, replicated within a zone, and can be resized without downtime. Types include standard (HDD), balanced, SSD, and extreme for different performance needs.

ul.li: Regional persistent disks replicate across two zones for high availability.
Snapshots provide incremental backups and cross-region replication.
Disks can be attached to multiple VMs in read-only mode.
Local SSDs offer highest IOPS but data is lost if VM stops.
Hyperdisks provide dynamically adjustable performance.

question.title: Cloud Operations Suite
question.scenario: An operations team needs to monitor application performance, collect logs, trace requests across microservices, and receive alerts when issues occur.
question.question-text: Which GCP offering provides integrated monitoring, logging, and application performance management?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Operations Suite provides monitoring, logging, and observability tools.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Operations Suite (formerly Stackdriver) is an integrated set of tools for monitoring, logging, and observability. It includes Cloud Monitoring for metrics and dashboards, Cloud Logging for log management, Cloud Trace for distributed tracing, and Error Reporting for exception tracking.

ul.li: Cloud Monitoring supports custom metrics and uptime checks.
Cloud Logging includes log-based metrics and log routing.
Cloud Trace tracks latency across distributed systems.
Cloud Profiler analyzes CPU and memory usage in production.
Alerting policies can trigger notifications via email, SMS, or Pub/Sub.

question.title: Cloud NAT
question.scenario: VMs in a private subnet need to access the internet for software updates and API calls, but should not have external IP addresses for security reasons.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides outbound internet access for VMs without external IP addresses?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud NAT provides outbound internet access without exposing VMs publicly.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud NAT (Network Address Translation) allows VMs without external IP addresses to access the internet for outbound connections while preventing unsolicited inbound connections. It's a managed service that scales automatically and doesn't require dedicated gateway VMs.

ul.li: Cloud NAT works at the VPC level with Cloud Router.
Automatic NAT IP allocation scales with connection needs.
Logging provides visibility into NAT gateway usage.
Private Google Access is different - it allows access to Google APIs, not general internet.
NAT rules can be configured per subnet or region.

question.title: Filestore
question.scenario: A media production company needs a shared file system accessible from multiple VMs simultaneously for collaborative video editing and rendering.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides fully managed NFS file shares?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Filestore provides managed NFS file shares for VMs and GKE.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Filestore is a fully managed file storage service that provides NFS file shares. Multiple VMs and GKE pods can mount the same Filestore instance for shared access. It's ideal for workloads requiring a shared file system like content management, rendering, and data analytics.

ul.li: Filestore tiers include Basic (HDD/SSD), High Scale, and Enterprise.
Enterprise tier provides regional high availability with 99.99% SLA.
Backups provide point-in-time snapshots of file shares.
Integration with GKE through PersistentVolume claims.
NetApp Cloud Volumes offers additional enterprise features.

question.title: Security Command Center
question.scenario: A security team needs centralized visibility into security threats, vulnerabilities, and misconfigurations across their GCP organization.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides centralized security and risk management for GCP resources?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Security Command Center is GCP's central security dashboard.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Security Command Center (SCC) is GCP's security and risk management platform. It discovers and inventories assets, detects threats and vulnerabilities, identifies misconfigurations, and provides compliance monitoring. It aggregates findings from multiple security services into one dashboard.

ul.li: Standard tier provides asset inventory and security health analytics.
Premium tier adds threat detection, compliance reports, and security analytics.
Event Threat Detection identifies suspicious activities in logs.
Container Threat Detection monitors GKE workloads.
Security Health Analytics finds misconfigurations automatically.

question.title: GPUs and TPUs
question.scenario: A machine learning team needs to train deep learning models faster than is possible with CPUs alone.
question.question-text: Which specialized hardware accelerators does GCP offer for machine learning training workloads?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GPUs and TPUs accelerate machine learning training and inference.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP offers NVIDIA GPUs and Google-designed Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) for accelerating ML workloads. GPUs are versatile and support various frameworks; TPUs are optimized specifically for TensorFlow and large-scale training. Both significantly reduce training time compared to CPUs.

ul.li: GPU types include NVIDIA A100, T4, V100, and L4.
TPU v4 pods can provide over 1 exaflop of computing power.
A2 and G2 machine families include attached GPUs.
Cloud TPUs are available on-demand or through reserved capacity.
Vertex AI integrates GPU/TPU provisioning for ML workflows.

question.title: Cloud Console and CLI
question.scenario: A new GCP user needs to manage their cloud resources using both graphical and command-line interfaces.
question.question-text: What are the two primary interfaces for managing GCP resources?

choices.choice: Cloud Console (web UI) and gcloud CLI

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Console is the web interface; gcloud is the command-line tool.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: The Cloud Console is a web-based graphical interface for managing GCP resources with dashboards, forms, and visualizations. The gcloud CLI is a command-line tool for scripting and automation. Both interfaces can manage the same resources; choice depends on the task and user preference.

ul.li: Cloud Console includes Cloud Shell for terminal access in browser.
gcloud is part of the Cloud SDK, which also includes gsutil and bq.
Client libraries (Python, Java, Go, etc.) provide programmatic access.
REST APIs underlie all interfaces for programmatic access.
Terraform and Deployment Manager enable infrastructure as code.

question.title: Data Transfer Options
question.scenario: A company needs to migrate 100 TB of data from their on-premises data center to Cloud Storage as quickly as possible.
question.question-text: Which GCP service enables offline data transfer for large datasets using physical appliances?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Transfer Appliance is a physical device for offline data migration.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Transfer Appliance is a secure, high-capacity storage device that Google ships to your location. You load your data onto it, ship it back, and Google uploads the data to Cloud Storage. It's ideal for large datasets (tens to hundreds of TB) when network transfer would take too long.

ul.li: Available in 100 TB and 480 TB capacities.
Data is encrypted with AES-256 before it leaves your site.
Storage Transfer Service is for online transfers from other clouds or URLs.
gsutil is for smaller transfers or scripted operations.
Transfer Service for on-premises data handles ongoing file-based transfers.

question.title: Shared VPC
question.scenario: An organization has multiple projects that need to share a common network infrastructure while maintaining separate billing and IAM for each project.
question.question-text: Which GCP feature allows multiple projects to use a common VPC network managed by a host project?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Shared VPC lets multiple projects use centrally managed networking.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Shared VPC allows an organization to connect resources from multiple service projects to a common VPC network hosted by a host project. This enables centralized network administration while allowing project-level resource management and billing. Network admins control the VPC; project users deploy resources.

ul.li: Host project owns the Shared VPC network and subnets.
Service projects contain resources that use the shared network.
Subnet-level permissions control which projects can use which subnets.
Firewall rules in the host project apply to all connected resources.
VPC Peering connects separate VPCs; Shared VPC shares one VPC.

question.title: Organization Policies
question.scenario: A company's security team needs to enforce that no one in the organization can create public Cloud Storage buckets, regardless of their IAM permissions.
question.question-text: Which GCP feature allows administrators to set constraints on how resources can be configured across an organization?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Organization policies set constraints that override individual permissions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Organization Policy Service allows centralized control over cloud resources through constraints. Unlike IAM (which controls who can do what), organization policies control what can be done regardless of permissions. Constraints can be set at organization, folder, or project level and are inherited downward.

ul.li: List constraints restrict which values are allowed (e.g., allowed regions).
Boolean constraints enable or disable capabilities (e.g., disable serial port access).
Constraints include restricting VM external IPs, disabling service account key creation.
Dry-run mode allows testing policies before enforcement.
Custom constraints enable organization-specific rules.

question.title: Container Registry and Artifact Registry
question.scenario: A development team needs a secure place to store and manage their Docker container images for deployment to GKE.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a managed repository for storing container images and other artifacts?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Artifact Registry is GCP's managed repository for containers and packages.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Artifact Registry is a fully managed, private repository for storing container images, language packages (Maven, npm, Python), and OS packages. It integrates with IAM for access control, vulnerability scanning for security, and CI/CD tools like Cloud Build.

ul.li: Artifact Registry replaced Container Registry with more features.
Supports Docker, Maven, npm, Python, Apt, and Yum formats.
Regional and multi-regional repository locations available.
Automatic vulnerability scanning identifies CVEs in images.
Remote repositories can cache packages from public registries.

question.title: Cloud Build
question.scenario: A development team wants to automate building container images and running tests whenever code is pushed to their repository.
question.question-text: Which GCP service provides a serverless CI/CD platform for building, testing, and deploying applications?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Cloud Build is GCP's serverless CI/CD platform.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Build is a fully managed CI/CD platform that executes builds on Google infrastructure. It can import source code, build containers, run tests, and deploy to GKE, Cloud Run, or other targets. Build configurations define steps as a series of container-based build steps.

ul.li: Triggers can start builds from Cloud Source Repositories, GitHub, or Bitbucket.
cloudbuild.yaml defines build steps, each running in a container.
Build steps share a workspace and can pass artifacts between steps.
Private pools provide dedicated, VPC-connected build workers.
Cloud Deploy adds managed continuous delivery to GKE and Cloud Run.

question.title: Object Lifecycle Management
question.scenario: A company stores log files in Cloud Storage and wants to automatically move them to cheaper storage after 30 days and delete them after one year.
question.question-text: Which Cloud Storage feature automates transitioning objects between storage classes or deleting them based on conditions?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Lifecycle rules automate storage class changes and deletions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Object Lifecycle Management lets you define rules that automatically transition objects to different storage classes or delete them based on conditions like age, creation date, or storage class. This helps optimize costs by moving infrequently accessed data to cheaper storage tiers automatically.

ul.li: Actions include Delete, SetStorageClass, and AbortIncompleteMultipartUpload.
Conditions include age, createdBefore, matchesStorageClass, and numNewerVersions.
Rules apply to all objects matching conditions; cannot target specific objects.
Versioned objects can be managed separately from live versions.
Lifecycle rules check objects daily and may take up to 24 hours to apply.

question.title: Private Google Access
question.scenario: VMs without external IP addresses need to access Google APIs like Cloud Storage and BigQuery without routing traffic through the public internet.
question.question-text: Which feature allows VMs with only internal IPs to reach Google APIs and services?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private Google Access enables internal-only VMs to reach Google APIs.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Private Google Access allows VMs with only internal IP addresses to reach Google APIs and services (like Cloud Storage, BigQuery, etc.) using internal routing rather than the public internet. It's enabled at the subnet level and doesn't require Cloud NAT for Google API access.

ul.li: Enabled per-subnet through VPC configuration.
Works with Google APIs using their public endpoints via internal routes.
Private Service Connect provides private endpoints within your VPC.
Cloud NAT is for general internet access, not Google APIs.
On-premises hosts can use Private Google Access through Cloud VPN or Interconnect.

question.title: IAM Roles Types
question.scenario: A company needs to grant specific permissions to team members, some needing full access to certain services while others need custom combinations of permissions.
question.question-text: What are the three types of IAM roles in GCP?

choices.choice: User, group, and service account roles

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: IAM has basic (primitive), predefined, and custom roles.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP IAM has three role types: Basic (primitive) roles are broad (Owner, Editor, Viewer) and apply across all services. Predefined roles are Google-managed with specific permissions for services. Custom roles let you create your own combination of permissions for least-privilege access.

ul.li: Basic roles are legacy; predefined roles are preferred for better security.
Predefined roles follow naming: roles/service.roleName (e.g., roles/storage.objectViewer).
Custom roles can only contain permissions available in predefined roles.
Role Recommender suggests least-privilege role improvements.
Predefined roles are automatically updated by Google with new permissions.

question.title: Anthos
question.scenario: An enterprise wants to run their containerized applications consistently across their on-premises data center, GCP, and AWS while using a single management interface.
question.question-text: Which Google platform enables consistent application management across on-premises, GCP, and other clouds?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Anthos is Google's multi-cloud and hybrid application platform.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Anthos is a managed application platform that extends Google Cloud services and engineering practices to hybrid and multi-cloud environments. It provides consistent development, operations, and security across GCP, on-premises, and other clouds using Kubernetes, service mesh, and configuration management.

ul.li: Anthos clusters on VMware and bare metal run on-premises.
Anthos attached clusters bring existing clusters under Anthos management.
Anthos Service Mesh provides traffic management and observability.
Config Management enables GitOps-style cluster configuration.
Binary Authorization enforces deploy-time security policies.

question.title: Deployment Manager
question.scenario: A DevOps team wants to define their GCP infrastructure in configuration files that can be version-controlled and repeatedly deployed.
question.question-text: Which GCP service allows you to create and manage cloud resources using declarative YAML or Python templates?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Deployment Manager is GCP's native infrastructure-as-code service.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Cloud Deployment Manager is an infrastructure deployment service that automates the creation and management of GCP resources. You define resources in YAML or Python templates, and Deployment Manager creates them with a single command. It supports parallel deployment and manages dependencies automatically.

ul.li: Templates can use Python or Jinja2 for dynamic configuration.
Deployments can be previewed before applying changes.
Type providers enable managing resources beyond GCP.
Config Connector is an alternative that uses Kubernetes-style resources.
Many teams prefer Terraform for multi-cloud IaC standardization.

question.title: GCP Free Tier
question.scenario: A student wants to learn GCP without incurring costs, using free resources for small-scale projects and experimentation.
question.question-text: What does GCP's Free Tier provide to new users?

choices.choice: $300 credit for 90 days plus always-free tier resources
Unlimited free access to all services for one year
Free access only during business hours
Free credits only for certified professionals

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: GCP offers $300 free credits plus always-free tier products.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: GCP's Free Tier includes two components: $300 in credits valid for 90 days for new users to try any GCP services, plus Always Free tier products that provide limited free usage of certain services indefinitely. This allows experimentation and learning without cost concerns.

ul.li: Always Free includes: 1 f1-micro VM, 5GB Cloud Storage, 1GB Firestore.
BigQuery offers 1TB of queries and 10GB storage free per month.
Cloud Functions provides 2 million invocations per month free.
Free tier limits vary by service and may change.
Billing alerts help avoid unexpected charges after free tier exhaustion.

term.name: GCP (Google Cloud Platform)
term.definition: A suite of cloud computing services running on the same infrastructure that Google uses internally for its end-user products.
term.exam-note: GCP is often used interchangeably with Google Cloud.

term.name: Compute Engine
term.definition: GCP's Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offering that provides virtual machines running on Google's infrastructure.
term.exam-note: Know the difference between Compute Engine (IaaS), App Engine (PaaS), and Cloud Functions (FaaS).

term.name: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE)
term.definition: A managed Kubernetes service for deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications.
term.exam-note: GKE Autopilot mode provides fully managed node operations.

term.name: Cloud Storage
term.definition: Object storage service for storing and accessing data on Google's infrastructure with high durability and availability.
term.exam-note: Remember the four storage classes: Standard, Nearline, Coldline, and Archive.

term.name: BigQuery
term.definition: A serverless, highly scalable enterprise data warehouse designed for business agility with built-in machine learning.
term.exam-note: BigQuery separates storage and compute, enabling independent scaling.

term.name: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
term.definition: A global, software-defined network that provides networking for GCP resources with firewall rules, routing, and private connectivity.
term.exam-note: VPCs are global; subnets are regional.

term.name: Identity and Access Management (IAM)
term.definition: The system for managing access to GCP resources by defining who (identity) has what access (role) to which resources.
term.exam-note: Understand the difference between basic, predefined, and custom roles.

term.name: Cloud Run
term.definition: A fully managed compute platform that runs stateless containers and automatically scales them based on incoming requests.
term.exam-note: Cloud Run can scale to zero and charges only for request processing time.

term.name: Cloud Pub/Sub
term.definition: A fully managed messaging service for building event-driven systems with at-least-once delivery guarantees.
term.exam-note: Pub/Sub decouples senders and receivers, enabling asynchronous communication.

term.name: Cloud SQL
term.definition: A fully managed relational database service for MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQL Server.
term.exam-note: Cloud SQL handles backups, replication, and patching automatically.
